critique: This document pertains to the National Industrial Recovery Act and fair competition codes within the graphic arts and newspaper publishing industries during the Franklin D. Roosevelt administration. It focuses on modifying previous executive orders to bring about uniformity in the application of certain provisions related to child labor and other aspects of the codes. The document reflects a moderate level of government intervention in the economy through the establishment and modification of these codes. There is no direct impact on immigration, civil liberties, or federalism. The document does not directly address social inclusion or ideological tilt in a pronounced way, but the focus on regulating child labor suggests a progressive stance. The modification of executive orders suggests a balanced approach to executive power, as it involves adjustments rather than outright expansion or restriction.
